summary: From 1986 onwards I have worked in international development cooperation. Until 2003, I have worked in Indonesia, Pakistan, Botswana and Uganda. Throughout my career overseas, I have combined project and programme management with capacity development of local organisations in various fields. In Indonesia, I co-developed a graduate study on Rural and Regional Development Planning at the Faculty of Geography, Gadjah Mada University, Yogyakarta. The courses and research programme forming the basis of this graduate study were developed in close collaboration with local staff and the Regional Planning Board. In Pakistan, I was advisor to the Ministry of Labour, Manpower and Overseas Pakistani, enhancing the capacity of Manpower Division staff to analyse data pertaining to the demand and supply of labour and the formulation of labour market related government policies. In Botswana, I was advisor to the Rural Development Coordination Division at the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning. Together with local staff I have worked on the development and implementation of a poverty reduction plan against a background of decentralisation of responsibilities. In Uganda, I led a team of advisors working in the West Nile region. The advisors technically prepared the district administrations to take up decentralised responsibilities. In 2005, I joined Oxfam Novib. First as team leader of the Linkis team and later as manager of the Global Link department. In both functions, I led a team of 15-20 officers. The Linkis team focussed on collaboration with Dutch organisations mobilising Dutch citizens to become active in international development. In the Global Link department (established in 2011), the work with Dutch organisations was combined with collaboration with global and international organisations and networks primarily engaged in strengthening civil society in the Global South.
